title: Sources of Magnetic Fields
content:
What we'll cover:

  • Introduction to Magnetic Fields
  • Magnetic Field from Moving Charges
  • Magnetic Field from Current-Carrying Wires
  • Ampere's Law
  • Solenoids and Toroids
  • Magnetic Materials
  • Earth's Magnetic Field

title: Introduction to Magnetic Fields
content:
• Magnetic fields are a fundamental force of nature, just like gravity and electricity.
  • They are created by moving electric charges.
  • We represent magnetic fields with magnetic field lines.
  • Units: Tesla (T)

title: Magnetic Field from Moving Charges
content:
• A single moving charge creates a magnetic field around it.
  • The strength and direction of the field depend on the charge's:
    • Magnitude: Larger charge = stronger field
    • Velocity: Faster speed = stronger field
    • Direction: Determined by the right-hand rule (explained later).

title: Right-Hand Rule (for a single moving charge)
content:
• Point your thumb in the direction of the charge's velocity (+ charge).
  • Curl your fingers.
  • Your fingers point in the direction of the magnetic field lines around the charge.

title: Magnetic Field from Current-Carrying Wires
content:
• A current is simply a flow of many moving charges.
  • Therefore, a current-carrying wire creates a magnetic field around it.
  • The strength and direction of the field depend on:
    • Current (I): Larger current = stronger field
    • Distance from the wire (r): Closer distance = stronger field

title: Right-Hand Rule (for a current-carrying wire)
content:
• Point your thumb in the direction of the current (conventional current: positive charge flow).
  • Curl your fingers around the wire.
  • Your fingers point in the direction of the magnetic field lines around the wire.

title: Magnetic Field Around a Long Straight Wire
content:
• The magnetic field lines form circles around the wire.
  • The field strength decreases as you move further away from the wire.
  • The formula to calculate the magnetic field (B) is:
    • B = (μ₀ * I) / (2π * r)
    • Where:
      • μ₀ is the permeability of free space (a constant)
      • I is the current
      • r is the distance from the wire

title: Ampere's Law
content:
• Ampere's Law is a powerful tool for calculating magnetic fields, especially in situations with symmetry.
  • It relates the integral of the magnetic field around a closed loop to the current passing through the loop.
  • ∫ B ⋅ dl = μ₀ * I_enclosed

title: Applying Ampere's Law
content:
1. Choose an Amperian Loop: A closed loop that exploits the symmetry of the problem.
  2. Calculate the Line Integral: ∫ B ⋅ dl (usually simplified by choosing loops where B is constant and parallel to dl).
  3. Determine the Enclosed Current: I_enclosed is the net current passing through the loop.
  4. Solve for B: Use Ampere's Law to calculate the magnetic field.

title: Solenoids
content:
• A solenoid is a coil of wire wound into a tight helix.
  • When current flows through the solenoid, it creates a relatively uniform magnetic field inside.
  • Outside the solenoid, the magnetic field is much weaker.

title: Magnetic Field Inside a Solenoid
content:
• The magnetic field inside an ideal solenoid (long and tightly wound) is approximately uniform and parallel to the axis of the solenoid.
  • B = μ₀ * n * I
    • Where:
      • μ₀ is the permeability of free space
      • n is the number of turns per unit length (N/L)
      • I is the current

title: Toroids
content:
• A toroid is a solenoid bent into a doughnut shape.
  • The magnetic field is confined almost entirely within the toroid.
  • Toroids are used in various applications, like fusion reactors.

title: Magnetic Field Inside a Toroid
content:
• The magnetic field inside a toroid is not uniform but varies with the distance from the center of the toroid.
  • B = (μ₀ * N * I) / (2π * r)
    • Where:
      • μ₀ is the permeability of free space
      • N is the total number of turns
      • I is the current
      • r is the distance from the center of the toroid

title: Magnetic Materials
content:
• Materials respond to magnetic fields in different ways.
  • Diamagnetic: Weakly repelled by magnetic fields.
  • Paramagnetic: Weakly attracted to magnetic fields.
  • Ferromagnetic: Strongly attracted to magnetic fields and can become permanently magnetized (e.g., iron, nickel, cobalt).

title: Ferromagnetism
content:
• Ferromagnetic materials have tiny regions called domains.
  • In an unmagnetized material, the domains are randomly oriented.
  • When a magnetic field is applied, the domains align, creating a strong magnetic field.
  • When the external field is removed, some alignment remains, resulting in a permanent magnet.

title: Hysteresis
content:
• The magnetization of a ferromagnetic material does not immediately return to zero when the applied magnetic field is removed. This lagging effect is called Hysteresis.
  • The Hysteresis loop shows the relationship between the magnetic field strength (H) and the magnetization (M) of the material.

title: Earth's Magnetic Field
content:
• The Earth has its own magnetic field, which protects us from harmful solar radiation.
  • It's thought to be generated by the movement of molten iron in the Earth's core (the dynamo effect).
  • The Earth's magnetic field is not static and can change over time.

title: Earth's Magnetic Poles
content:
• The Earth's magnetic poles are not located at the geographic poles.
  • The magnetic north pole is actually located in the Arctic region of Canada.
  • The magnetic poles also drift over time.

title: Applications of Magnetic Fields
content:
• Electric Motors: Magnetic forces are used to rotate coils of wire.
  • Generators: Moving a conductor through a magnetic field induces a current.
  • MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to create detailed images of the body.
  • Data Storage: Hard drives use magnetic fields to store data on a magnetic disk.
  • Maglev Trains: Use powerful magnets to levitate and propel trains at high speeds.

title: Summary
content:
• Moving charges and currents create magnetic fields.
  • Ampere's Law is a powerful tool for calculating magnetic fields.
  • Solenoids and toroids produce relatively uniform magnetic fields.
  • Magnetic materials respond differently to magnetic fields.
  • The Earth has its own magnetic field.
